text: These are also proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied out.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the glory of God to conceal the word, but the honour of kings is to search out the word.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the height of the heavens and depth of the earth and for the heart of kings, there is no investigation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take away the dross from the silver, and a vessel shall come forth for the finer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take away the wicked from before the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not praise thyself in the presence of the king, and do not stand in the place of great men;
speaker: Narrator

text: for it is better that it be said unto thee, Come up here than that thou should be put lower in the presence of the prince whom thine eyes have seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not go forth hastily to strive lest thou know not what to do in the end thereof when thy neighbour has put thee to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: Debate thy cause with thy neighbour himself and do not uncover the secret to another
speaker: Narrator

text: lest he that hears it put thee to shame and thine infamy not turn away.
speaker: Narrator

text: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold inscribed with silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: As an earring of gold and an ornament of fine gold, so is he who reproves a wise man who has a docile ear.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, so is a faithful messenger to those that send him, for he refreshes the soul of his master.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever boasts in a gift of falsehood is like clouds and wind without rain.
speaker: Narrator

text: By long forbearing a prince is persuaded, and a soft tongue breaks the bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou found honey? eat so much as is sufficient for thee lest thou be filled therewith, and vomit it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Withdraw thy foot from thy neighbour’s house lest he be weary of thee and so hate thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man that bears false witness against his neighbour is a maul and a sword and a sharp arrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble is like a broken tooth, and a foot out of joint.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he that takes away a garment in cold weather and as vinegar upon soap, so is he that sings songs to a heavy heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: If thy enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat, and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink,
speaker: Narrator

text: for thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head, and the LORD shall reward thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: The north wind drives away rain, so does an angry countenance a backbiting tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to dwell in the corner of the housetop than with a brawling woman and in a wide house.
speaker: Narrator

text: As cold waters to a thirsty soul, so is good news from a far country.
speaker: Narrator

text: A righteous man falling down before the wicked is as a troubled fountain and a corrupt spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not good to eat much honey, so for men to search their own glory is not glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man whose spirit has no restraint is like a city that is broken down and without walls.
speaker: Narrator

text: As snow in summer and as rain in harvest, so honour is not suited for a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the sparrow in its wandering, as the swallow in its flight, so the curse causeless shall never come.
speaker: Narrator

text: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the ass, and a rod for the fool’s back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never answer a fool according to his folly lest thou also be like unto him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Answer the fool showing him his folly lest he be wise in his own conceit.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that gives responsibility to one who is not able to carry it out is like him that sends a message by the hand of a fool, and he shall drink the damage.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like unto the way that the one who is lame walks, so is a proverb in the mouth of the fool.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he that binds the stone in the sling, so is he that gives honour to a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text: As thorns sunk into the hand of one who is drunk, so is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text: The great God that formed all things rewards both the fool and transgressors.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a dog returns to his vomit, so the fool returns to his folly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? there is more hope of a fool than of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The slothful man saith, There is a lion in the way; a lion is in the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the door turns upon his hinges, so does the slothful upon his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The slothful hides his hand in his bosom; it grieves him to bring it again to his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sluggard is wiser in his own conceit than seven men that can give him counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that passes by and meddles with strife not belonging to him is like one that takes a dog by the ears.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a mad man who casts firebrands, arrows, and death,
speaker: Narrator

text: so is the man that destroys his friend and says, Am I not in sport?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where there is no wood, the fire goes out, so where there is no talebearer, the strife ceases.
speaker: Narrator

text: Charcoal for burning coals and wood for fire, and a contentious man to kindle strife.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of a talebearer seem smooth, but they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Burning lips and a wicked heart are like a potsherd covered with silver dross.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that hates dissembles with his lips and lays up deceit within him;
speaker: Narrator

text: when he speaks fair, do not believe him, for there are seven abominations in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though his hatred is covered up in the desert, his wickedness shall be showed before the whole congregation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever digs a pit shall fall therein, and he that rolls a stone, it will return upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A lying tongue hates those that are afflicted by it, and a flattering mouth works ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Boast not thyself of tomorrow for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let another man praise thee and not thine own mouth; a stranger, and not thine own lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: A stone is heavy and the sand weighty; but a fool’s wrath is heavier than them both.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wrath is cruel, and anger is impetuous, but who is able to stand before envy?
speaker: Narrator

text: Open rebuke is better than secret love.
speaker: Narrator

text: Faithful are the wounds of a friend, but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.
speaker: Narrator

text: The full soul loathes a honeycomb, but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a bird that wanders from her nest, so is a man that wanders from his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart, so does the sweetness of a man’s friend by hearty counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not forsake thine own friend and thy father’s friend, neither go into thy brother’s house in the day of thy calamity, for better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far off.
speaker: Narrator

text: My son, be wise and make my heart glad that I may answer him that reproaches me.
speaker: Narrator

text: A prudent man foresees the evil and hides himself, but the simple pass on and are hurt by it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger and take a pledge of him that is surety for a strange woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that blesses his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A continual dripping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever hides her hides the wind, because the oil in his right hand cries out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Iron sharpens iron; so a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever keeps the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof, so he that waits on his master shall be honoured.
speaker: Narrator

text: As in water face corresponds to face, so the heart of man to man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sheol and hell are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the fining pot tries the silver and the furnace the gold; so the man is tried by the mouth of whoever praises him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though thou should bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, yet his foolishness will not depart from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be thou diligent to know the countenance of thy sheep, and put thy heart into thy herds.
speaker: Narrator

text: For riches are not for ever, and does the crown endure to every generation?
speaker: Narrator

text: The tender grass shows itself, and the hay appears, and the herbs of the mountains are reaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lambs are for thy clothing, and the goats are for the price of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou shalt have goats’ milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household, and for the maintenance of thy maidens.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wicked flee when no man pursues, but the righteous are bold as a young lion.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the rebellion of the land, many are its princes, but by the man of understanding and wisdom the land shall remain stable.
speaker: Narrator

text: A poor man that oppresses the poor is like a sweeping rain which leaves no food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those that forsake the law praise the wicked, but such as keep the law contend with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Evil men do not understand judgment, but those that seek the LORD understand all things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Better is the poor that walks in his perfection than he that is perverse in his ways, though he is rich.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever keeps the law is a wise son, but he that is a companion of gluttons shames his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that by usury and unjust gain increases his substance, he shall gather it for him that will pity the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that turns away his ear from hearing the law, even his prayer shall be abomination.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever causes the upright to go astray in an evil way, he shall fall himself into his own pit, but the perfect shall inherit every good thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rich man is wise in his own conceit, but the poor that has understanding is wiser than he.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the righteous rejoice, there is great glory, but when the wicked rise, the sane man hides himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that covers his sins shall not prosper, but whosoever confesses and forsakes them shall attain mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed is the man that fears God always, but he that hardens his heart shall fall into evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a roaring lion and a hungry bear, so is a wicked ruler over the poor people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prince void of intelligence is also a great oppressor, but he that hates covetousness shall prolong his days.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man that does violence to the blood of any person shall flee all the way to the grave, and no one shall sustain him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever walks in integrity shall be saved, but he that is perverse in his ways shall fall into one of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that tills his land shall be filled with bread, but he that follows after vain persons shall be filled with poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man of truth shall abound with blessings, but he that makes haste to be rich shall not be absolved.
speaker: Narrator

text: To have respect of persons in judgment is not good; even for a piece of bread, man will transgress.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that hastens to be rich has an evil eye and does not consider that poverty shall come upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that rebukes a man, afterwards shall find more favour than he that flatters with the tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever robs his father or his mother and says, It is no transgression; the same is the companion of the destroyer.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that is of a proud heart stirs up strife, but he that puts his trust in the LORD shall be made fat.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that trusts in his own heart is a fool, but whosoever walks in wisdom, he shall be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that gives unto the poor shall never lack, but he that hides his eyes from the poor shall have many a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the wicked rise, sane men hide themselves; but when they perish, the righteous multiply.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that being often reproved hardens his neck shall suddenly be destroyed and that without remedy.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the righteous are in authority, the people rejoice, but when the wicked bear rule, the people mourn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever loves wisdom causes his father to rejoice, but he that maintains harlots shall lose his inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king by judgment establishes the land, but he that receives gifts shall overthrow it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man that flatters his neighbour spreads a net for his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the transgression of an evil man there is a snare, but the righteous shall sing and rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text: The righteous considers the cause of the poor, but the wicked does not understand wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Scornful men bring a city into a snare, but wise men turn away wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a wise man contends with a foolish man, whether he rages or laughs, there is no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bloodthirsty hate the perfect, but the just seek his soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fool gives full rein to his spirit, but the wise man in the end will bring it into rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of the ruler who hearkens unto the lying word, all his ministers are evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poor and the usurer meet together; the LORD lightens both their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king that judges the poor with truth, his throne shall be established for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rod and reproof give wisdom, but a child left to himself shall bring his mother to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the wicked are multiplied, transgression increases, but the righteous shall see their fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Correct thy son, and he shall give thee rest; he shall give delight unto thy soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Without prophetic vision, the people shall perish, but he that keeps the law is blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text: A slave will not be corrected by words, for though he understands he will not obey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope of a fool than of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that gives freely unto his slave from a child shall have him become his son in the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angry man stirs up strife, and the furious man abounds in transgression.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man’s pride shall bring him low, but honour shall uphold the humble in spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whosoever is partner with a thief hates his own soul; he hears cursing, and does not disclose it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fear of man brings a snare, but whosoever puts his trust in the LORD shall be lifted up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many seek the ruler’s favour, but each man’s judgment comes from the LORD.
speaker: Narrator

text: An unjust man is an abomination to the just, and he that is upright in the way is abomination to the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of Agur the son of Jakeh, even the prophecy: the man spoke unto Ithiel, even unto Ithiel and Ucal,
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely I am more carnal than any man and have not the understanding of a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: I neither learned wisdom nor have the knowledge of the holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who has ascended up into heaven, or descended? who has gathered the wind in his fists? who has bound the waters in a garment? who has established all the ends of the earth? what is his name, and what is his son’s name, if thou canst tell?
speaker: Narrator

text: Every word of God is pure: he is a shield unto those that put their trust in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not add unto his words, lest he reprove thee, and thou be found a liar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two things have I required of thee; do not deny me them before I die:
speaker: Narrator

text: Remove far from me vanity and lies: give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with the bread of my judgment:
speaker: Narrator

text: Lest I be full, and deny thee, and say, Who is the LORD? or lest I be poor, and steal, and blaspheme the name of my God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not accuse a slave in the presence of his master, lest he curse thee, and thou be found guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a generation that curses their father, and does not bless their mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a generation that are pure in their own eyes, and yet is not washed from their filthiness.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a generation, O how lofty are their eyes! and their eyelids are lifted up.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a generation, whose teeth are as swords, and their molars as knives, to devour the poor from off the earth, and the destitute from among men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The horseleach has two daughters, which are called, Give, give. There are three things that are never satisfied, yea, four things say not, It is enough:
speaker: Narrator

text: Sheol; and the barren womb; the earth that is not filled with water; and the fire that never says, It is enough.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eye that mocks at his father, and despises the teaching of his mother, the ravens shall pluck it out of the river, and the young eagles shall eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are three things which are hidden from me, yea, four which I know not:
speaker: Narrator

text: The track of the eagle in the air; the track of the serpent upon the rock; the track of the ship in the midst of the sea; and the track of the man in the maid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Such is the track of an adulterous woman; she eats, and wipes her mouth, and says, I have done no wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For three things the earth is disquieted, and the fourth it cannot bear:
speaker: Narrator

text: For a slave when he reigns; and a fool when he is filled with bread;
speaker: Narrator

text: for a rejected woman when she is married; and a handmaid that is heir to her mistress.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are four things which are little upon the earth, but they are wiser than the wise men:
speaker: Narrator

text: The ants are a people not strong, yet they prepare their food in the summer;
speaker: Narrator

text: the conies are but a feeble folk, yet they make their houses in the rocks;
speaker: Narrator

text: the locusts have no king, yet all of them go forth by bands;
speaker: Narrator

text: the spider takes hold with her hands and is in kings’ palaces.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are three things which have a magnificent walk; yea, the fourth is stately in going:
speaker: Narrator

text: The lion which is strongest among beasts and does not turn away for any;
speaker: Narrator

text: the greyhound who is girded up of loins; a he goat also, and the king, against whom no one rises up.
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou hast fallen, it is because thou hast lifted thyself up; and if thou hast thought evil, lay thine hand upon thy mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely the churning of milk brings forth butter and the wringing of the nose brings forth blood; so the forcing of wrath brings forth strife.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of King Lemuel, the prophecy with which his mother taught him.
speaker: Narrator

text: What, my son? and what, the son of my womb? and what, the son of my vows?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not give thy strength nor thy ways unto the women who destroy kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine; nor is beer for princes
speaker: Narrator

text: lest they drink and forget the law and pervert the judgment of any of the afflicted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give beer unto him that is ready to perish and wine unto those that have heavy hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: They drink and forget their need and remember their misery no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Open thy mouth for those who cannot speak in the judgment of all the sons of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Open thy mouth, judge righteously, and plead the cause of the poor and destitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who can find a valiant woman? for her price is far above precious stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heart of her husband safely trusts in her, so that he shall have no need of spoil.
speaker: Narrator

text: She will do him good and not evil all the days of her life.
speaker: Narrator

text: She sought wool and flax and worked willingly with her hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: She was like the merchants’ ships; she brings her food from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text: She rose up even at night and gave food to her family and a portion to her maidens.
speaker: Narrator

text: She considered the inheritance and bought it; with the fruit of her hands she planted a vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: She girded her loins with strength and strengthened her arms.
speaker: Narrator

text: She perceived that her merchandise was good; her fire did not go out by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: She laid her hands to the spindle, and her hands held the distaff.
speaker: Narrator

text: She stretched out her hand to the poor; yea, she reached forth her hands to the destitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: She shall not be afraid of the snow for her family, for all her family is clothed with double garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: She makes herself tapestries; her clothing is of fine linen and purple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her husband is known in the gates when he sits among the elders of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: She made fine linen and sold it and delivered girdles unto the merchant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Strength and glory is her clothing, and she shall laugh in the last day.
speaker: Narrator

text: She opened her mouth with wisdom, and the law of mercy is upon her tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text: She looks well to the ways of her household and does not eat bread in idleness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her sons rose up and called her blessed; her husband also, and he praised her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many daughters have done valiantly, but thou dost excel them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Grace is deceitful, and beauty is vain, but the woman that fears the LORD shall be praised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give her of the fruit of her hands, and let her own works praise her in the gates.
speaker: Narrator
